metadata.title: Selective laser melting of nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg alloy with high fracture strength and ductility

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Acta Materialia
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/actamat
Full length article
Selective laser melting of nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg alloy with high fracture strength and ductility
X.P. Li a, *, G. Ji b, Z. Chen c, ***, A. Addad b, Y. Wu c, H.W. Wang c, J. Vleugels d, J. Van Humbeeck d, J.P. Kruth a, **
a KU Leuven (University of Leuven), Department of Mechanical Engineering, Leuven, 3001, Belgium b Unit e Mat eriaux et Transformations, CNRS UMR 8207, Universit e Lille 1, Villeneuve d'Ascq, 59655, France c State Key Laboratory of Metal Matrix Composites, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, PR China d KU Leuven (University of Leuven), Department of Materials Engineering, Leuven, 3001, Belgium
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 16 January 2017 Received in revised form 22 February 2017 Accepted 22 February 2017 Available online 23 February 2017
Keywords: Additive manufacturing Selective laser melting Aluminium alloys Metal matrix composites Mechanical properties
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author. *** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: xiaopeng.li@kuleuven.be (X.P (Z. Chen).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.actamat.2017.02.062 1359-6454/© 2017 Acta Materialia Inc. Published by E
a b s t r a c t
An in-situ nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg composite (NTD-Al) powder was fabricated by gas-atomisation for selective laser melting (SLM). Fully dense and crack-free NTD-Al samples were produced using SLM. In contrast to the NTD-Al powder without cell-like microstructure, the SLMed NTD-Al had a textureless microstructure, consisting of fine grains and cells, with well dispersed nano-TiB2 particles inside the grains and rod-like nano-Si precipitates inside the cells. Both nano-TiB2 particles and nano-Si precipitates exhibited a highly coherent interface with the Al matrix, indicative of a strong interfacial bonding. The formation of this microstructure was attributed to the sequential solidification of non-equilibrium and eutectic Al-Si upon rapid cooling during SLM. As a result, the SLMed NTD-Al showed a very high ultimate tensile strength ~530 MPa, excellent ductility ~15.5% and high microhardness ~191 HV0.3, which were higher than most conventionally fabricated wrought and tempered Al alloys, previously SLMed Al-Si alloys and nano-grained 7075 Al. The underlying mechanisms for this strength and ductility enhancement were discussed and a correlation between this novel microstructure and the superior mechanical properties was established. This study provides new and deep insights into the fabrication of metal matrix nanocomposites by SLM from in-situ pre-decorated composite powder.
© 2017 Acta Materialia Inc. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As an emerging powder bed additive manufacturing technique, selective laser melting (SLM) has enjoyed a rapid development in the past decade [1e3]. Its characteristic layer-wise fabrication process enables the rapid production of complex geometry components without the time-consuming mould design process [4,5]. In addition, the fast cooling rate (103e106 C/s) also offers a promising alternative to fabricate components with unique and highly tailorable microstructures, e.g. ultrafine, gradient, metastable or amorphous microstructures [6e14]. All of these have rendered SLM one of the frontier manufacturing techniques across
. Li), zhe.chen@sjtu.edu.cn
lsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a broad range of industries, including aerospace, automotive, biomedical and other niche industries [5]. However, one of the key hurdles impeding further applications of SLM is the current severe limitation on materials suitable for SLM processing. Up till now, only a very limited number (less than 20) of metal powders including certain Al-, Ti-, Ni-alloys and steels possess acceptable processability and can be used to produce dense components by SLM [2e5]. This is far from adequate for both current and future applications and industrial take-up of SLM. To eliminate this bottleneck, it is crucial to design and develop suitable materials with acceptable SLM processability. Therefore, more and more efforts have recently been made to expand the materials palette for SLM and metal matrix composites are of major focus [15,16].
Recently, fully dense Al-, Ti- and Fe-based metal matrix composites with secondary metal or ceramic particles as additions have been successfully fabricated using SLM with improved mechanical properties [17e23]. For example, Gu et al. reported on the fabrication of Al nanocomposites with a novel ring-structured TiC
reinforcement by SLM of AlSi10Mg with nano-TiC ceramic particles [17]. The fabricated nanocomposites exhibited improved tensile strength (486 MPa) and high microhardness (188 HV0.1). In addition, they also reported on the fabrication of Ti composites by SLM of a mixture of pure Ti and micrometer-sized SiC particles [21]. The microstructure showed a unique network of distributed TiC and a sub-micron dendritic morphology, which resulted in high microhardness (980 HV0.2) and a low friction coefficient. Song et al. successfully SLMed Fe-based nanocomposites with micrometersized Fe and nano-SiC particles [18]. The fabricated parts showed a microstructure with homogeneously distributed nano-SiC particles, which resulted from the decomposition of the micrometer SiC starting powder, resulting in a very high tensile strength (753MPa). Apart from this, similar attempts were also made to fabricate other metal matrix composites via SLM including in-situ Ti-TiB2 composites [19], a novel b-Ti composites from Ti6Al4V ELI and micrometer-sized Mo [20], in-situ TiC reinforced Ti-Al composites from pure Ti, Al and graphite [22] and TiB reinforced near a-Ti metal composites from pure Ti and micrometer-sized CrB2 [23].
As mentioned above, current SLM fabrication of metal matrix composites largely relies on a mechanical mixing process (e.g. ball milling) to ensure a homogenousmixture of the startingmetals and ceramic particles before SLM. As such, the drawbacks of this process are apparent: (1) in most cases, the added fine secondary particles (diameter 5 mm) would deteriorate the flowability of the matrix powder [2]; (2) due to different laser absorptivity of the ceramic particles, an apparent difference in thermal history between the ceramic particles and the metals would be inevitable, which can also affect or complicate the melt pool behavior [24]; and (3) although some in-situ reaction can be introduced to improve the interfacial bonding between the reinforcement particles and the matrix [16], this improvement is limited because the wettability of the metal matrix and secondary metal or ceramic particles is difficult to control. These challenges all together would pose significant difficulty in optimising the SLM process of the metal matrix composites to achieve fully dense and crack-free components. As a consequence, it becomes also difficult to tailor the microstructure and hence obtain the desired mechanical properties of the metal matrix composites.
In this study, a nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg composite (NTDAl) powder was gas-atomised for SLM. The microstructures and mechanical properties of the NTD-Al powder and SLMed NTD-Al were systematically characterised. The SLMed NTD-Al exhibited very high tensile strength, excellent ductility and high microhardness. The underlying reason was attributed to the novel microstructure consisting of fine grains and cells, strengthened by welldispersed nano-TiB2 particles and nano-Si precipitates.

sections.heading: 2.1. Fabrication of nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg powder
sections.text:
The nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg (NTD-Al) powder used in this study was fabricated in two steps. Firstly, nano-TiB2 was introduced into pure Al (99.99%, CHALCO) in a high-purity graphite crucible in air using an electrical resistance furnace at 900 C via the in-situ reaction method. Reactive salts of K2TiF6 and KBF4 with high purity ( 99.0%, Taian Health Chemical Co., Ltd.) were slowly added into themolten Al metal during melt stirring at 600 rpm for 15min. After slag removal, the molten composite was cast into an iron mould to obtain a nano-TiB2 reinforced pure Al composite master alloy. Secondly, Mg (99.99%, CHALCO) and Al-Si master (99.99%, CHALCO) alloys were subsequently added into the re-molten presynthesized nano-TiB2 reinforced Al composite master alloy and homogenized for 10 min. NTD-Al powder was produced by an
in-house built gas-atomiser using He gas. The chemical composition of the powder is 9.81 wt% Si, 0.32 wt%Mg,11.6 wt% TiB2 (~7 vol %) with Al balance, measured through inductively coupled plasma atomic emission analysis (ICP-AES). The average diameter of the nano-TiB2 particles is ~100 nm, as reported elsewhere [25] and the sieved powder fraction between 15 and 45 mmwas used for the SLM process.

sections.heading: 2.2. Selective laser melting process
sections.text: NTD-Al specimens (10 10 6 mm) and tensile bars were produced on an in-house built selective laser melting machine which is equipped with a fibre laser, with a wavelength of 1.06 mm and maximum power of 300 W on the part bed. An inert, high purity ( 99.99%) argon gas atmosphere flow was used during the whole process to minimise oxidation. Different laser powers (200e300 W) and scan speeds (800e2000 mm/s) were used. The powder layer thickness was fixed at 30 mm, the scan spacing at 105 mm, without pre-heating. The density of the SLMed NTD-Al was measured using the Archimedes method (a theoretical density ~2.81 g/cm3 was used).

sections.heading: 2.3. Microstructure characterisation
sections.text:
The microstructure of the NTD-Al powder and SLMed materials was characterised using a FEI-Nova NanoSEM 450 scanning electronmicroscope (SEM, acceleration voltage 10 kV, working distance 5 mm) and a FEI Tecnai G2 transmission electron microscope (TEM, operated at 200 kV). A state-of-the-art FEI Titan Themis 300 TEM, equipped with a probe aberration corrector and a highly efficient (4 quadrant) energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) system and operated at 200 kV, was further used for atomic and nano-scale characterization in the scanning TEM (STEM) mode. The probe size was set to 0.1 nmwith a convergence semi-angle of 22.5 mrad. The collection angle of the high angle annular dark field (HAADF) detector was in the range of 80e150 mrad. The size and morphology of the grain structure were investigated by image analysis software Image Pro Plus. At least ten different regions on each sample were taken for image analysis. The TEM samples from the powder were prepared using focused ion beam (FIB). The TEM samples from the SLMed NTD-Al materials were mechanically polished and finally thinned by a Precision Ion Polishing System (Gatan PIPS™) where low-angle and low-current polishing conditions were used in conjunction with a liquid nitrogen cold stage. Texture and grain size of SLMed NTD-Al material were characterised using electron backscattered diffraction (EBSD) using a TSL orientation imaging microscope system mounted on a FEI-Nova NanoSEM 450 SEM. A step size of 0.1 mm was used in all EBSD measurements.
The phase formation in the powder and SLMed NTD-Al materials were characterised using X-ray diffraction (XRD, Siemens D500 powder diffractometer, Cu Ka target, operated at 40 kV and 40 mAwith a step size of 0.02 and scanning speed 2 /min, all XRD scans were done on the plane parallel to the SLM building direction).

sections.heading: 2.4. Mechanical properties
sections.text:
Tensile tests were carried out on SLMed and machined specimens (gauge length ~4 2 16 mm, prepared by electrical discharge machining, EDM), using an Instron 5982 machine at a constant strain rate of 1 mm/min. Strain was measured with a 12.5 mm gauge length extensometer. Samples were aligned perpendicular to the build direction and a total of 8 samples were tested. The microhardness of the SLMed material was measured on a Zwick-3202 Vickers hardness tester with a load of 0.3 kg and a
total of 40 points were measured.

sections.heading: 2.5. Laser absorptivity
sections.text:
The laser absorptivity of the NTD-Al powder was measured using diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) and for comparison non-decorated AlSi10Mg powder (LPW, 15e45 mm) was also measured. DRS was carried out in the 250e2250 nm wavelength range using an UV-Visible-NIR Lambda 950 Perkin Elmer spectrometer equipped with a 150 mm diameter integrating sphere coated with Spectralon with 1 nm spectral resolution. A Spectralon reference was used to measure the 100% reflectance and internal attenuators were used to determine zero reflectance in order to remove background and noise. The powders were placed in a quartz cuvette, sealed, and mounted on a Teflon sample holder for the DRS measurement. The measured reflectance spectra were subsequently converted to Kubelka-Munk (K-M) absorption factors to evaluate the absorption spectra of the powders. This conversion was performed using the K-M equation: f ðRÞ ¼ ð1 RÞ 2
2R , with R, the measured laser reflectivity of the powders.

sections.heading: 3.1. Nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg powder
sections.text:
The morphology and cross-section of the nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg (NTD-Al) powder are shown in the SEM images in Fig. 1, revealing the powder had a spherical morphology (Fig. 1a) with some nano-TiB2 particles on the powder surface (Fig. 1b). The average grain size varied in a range from 4 to 8 mm (Fig. 1c), depending on the powder particle size. The nano-TiB2 particles distribute non-uniformly in the Al-Si matrix in a reticulated
manner along the grain boundaries (Fig. 1c). Agglomeration of nano-TiB2 particles can be readily seen, especially in the triplepockets of the grains. No nano-TiB2 particles were detected inside the grains of the NTD-Al powder (Fig. 1d).

sections.heading: 3.2. Optimisation of the selective laser melting process
sections.text: The relationship between the relative density of the SLMed NTD-Al samples and the laser energy density Ep used in SLM is shown in Fig. 2a, which shows a typical curve for SLMed metal materials like Al and Ti alloys [26,27]. The relative density increases first with increasing Ep and then decreases with further increasingEp. The highest relative density 99.5% was achieved at Ep ~95 J/mm3. The relationship between the relative density of the fabricated material and the laser power P used at a constant Ep is shown in Fig. 2b. At the sameEp, the relative density of the material increased with increasing P up to the maximum laser power P ~300 W of the SLM machine used in this study. When P is below 250W, the relative density of thematerial suddenly dropped below 98.5%. For achieving a fully dense part within a short scanning time, a laser power of 300 W was chosen as optimum parameter in this study. The components for the following microstructure and mechanical properties study were all built at 300 W, as shown in the inset of Fig. 2b.

sections.heading: 3.3. Microstructure of the SLMed NTD-Al
sections.text:
The XRD patterns of the NTD-Al powder and SLMed NTD-Al components are shown in Fig. 3; both composed of face-centred cubic (fcc) Al-Si and hexagonal TiB2 phases. There was no apparent difference in the XRD patterns between the powder and the fabricated material within the limitation of the XRD detection (~1 wt%), implying that no formation of new phases occurred or preferred grain orientation (crystallographic texture) developed during the SLM.
The microstructure of the SLMed NTD-Al is shown in Fig. 4a e c, where brighter area is TiB2 and grey area is Al-Si matrix. No cracks or porosity can be observed, implying a good processability of the powder (Fig. 4a). In contrast to the starting powder, a fine cell microstructure with a size 1 mm can be observed (Fig. 4b) (it should be noted that the terminology throughout the paper, e.g. cells, is used according to the previous literature onmicrostructures during solidification of alloys [28]). The nano-TiB2 particles mainly distributed along the cell boundaries and limited agglomeration at the triple-pokects of the cells can be seen (Fig. 4b). A higher magnification of the cells is shown in Fig. 4c. The microstructure of the SLMed material cross-sectioned along the building direction (BD) is shown in the EBSD inverse pole figures (IPF) in Fig. 4d. Unlike previously reported SLMed Al-Si alloys, only equiaxed grains can be seen across the section. In contrast to previously reported SLMed Al-Si alloys where strong texture was developed as a result of the directional global heat flux and thermal gradient during SLM [29e31], the Al grains in this study were randomly oriented which can be confirmed by the random colour in the IPF image, consistent with the XRD results shown in Fig. 3. The grain size distribution measured in the BD cross-section is shown in Fig. 4e, showing a bimodal grain size distribution consisting of fine and coarse grains. It is also clear that the SLMed NTD-Al had a much smaller grain size (average size ~2 mm) than the starting powder (average size ~4e8 mm). This is also much smaller than the grain size in previously reported SLMed Al-Si alloys (~10 mm) [13].
The TEM bright field (BF) image of the cells in the SLMed NTD-Al is shown in Fig. 5a. Similar to Fig. 4c, nano-TiB2 particles were detected mainly along the cell boundaries. The statistical size distribution of the cells is given in Fig. 5b. Most of the cells had a size
below 500 nm and showed equiaxed morphology. In addition, from the Kikuchi patterns of two neighbouring cells in Fig. 5c, it is clear that the cells within one Al grain had a slight crystal orientation deviation. The STEM HAADF image and EDX mapping of the cells are shown in Fig. 6. Ti and B were detected along the grain boundaries and the cell boundaries were also enriched with Si and Mg, consistent with the TEM BF image in Fig. 5. To further investigate nano-TiB2 at the cell boundaries, a high resolution STEM (HRSTEM) image of the interface between the nano-TiB2 and the Al is shown in Fig. 7a. The corresponding STEM EDXmapping of the Al and Ti was given in Figures b and c, respectively. It can be seen from the corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) patterns in Fig. 7def, nano-TiB2 and Al had a highly coherent interface with crystal orientation relations (ORs), i.e. [11e20]TiB2//[110]Al, (0001)TiB2// (-111)Al and (-110-1)TiB2//(001)Al being determined, the first OR was in agreement with previously reported ORs between TiB2 and Al in Al casting [32].
A close look at the Si distribution in the EDX mapping results in Fig. 6, reveals that some Si was found inside the cells. In order to confirm this, the TEM BF image of the cells at higher magnification was shown in Fig. 8. It is clear that nano-sized precipitates were found inside the cells. These relatively homogeneously distributed nano precipitates had a rod-like morphology, which was different from previously reported spherical Si in SLMed Al-12Si alloy. Interestingly, these precipitates also had a certain orientation relation with each other in the Al matrix, either parallel or perpendicular to each other, as can be clearly seen in Fig. 8b. An HRSTEM HAADF image and the corresponding FFT pattern of the nano precipitates are shown in Fig. 9. It showed that the nano
precipitates were pure Si. More importantly, the Si had a perfect coherent interface with the Al matrix, as evidenced by the HRSTEM and FFT pattern. The STEM EDX mapping results of the areas marked in Fig. 8b were also shown in Fig. 10. Only Si was found in the nano precipitates, consistent with the HRSTEM and FFT results shown in Fig. 9.

sections.heading: 3.4. Mechanical properties of the SLMed material
sections.text: The tensile stress-strain curve and the fracture surface of the SLMed NTD-Al material are shown in Fig. 11. The material had an ultimate tensile strength ~530 ± 16 MPa and elongation of 15.5 ± 1.2% before fracture. No apparent necking was observed during tensile testing. Equiaxed dimples with a size ranging from submicrometer to 5 mm were observed across the whole fracture surface, as shown in the insets of Fig. 11, which was indicative of a highly ductile fracture behaviour. A careful observation showed that the edges of the dimples passed through both Al grain boundaries and cell boundaries. Nano-TiB2 particles were observed in the dimple pockets. The mechanical properties of the SLMed NTD-Al material were compared with other Al alloys and their composites fabricated using different techniques, as shown in Fig. 12. The SLMed NTD-Al material has a superior combination of strength and ductility, which is comparable to or higher than most conventionally fabricated and tempered wrought 2xxx to 7xxx Al alloys, cast Al-Si alloys, previously reported SLM fabricated Al-Si alloys, coarse-grain and nano-structural 7075 Al, as well as graphene-, carbon nanotubes (CNTs)-reinforced Al composites [7,17,33e37]. In addition, the Vickers microhardness of the SLMed NTD-Al material was 191 ± 4 HV0.3.

sections.heading: 4.1. SLM processability of the nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg powder
sections.text:
The SLM processability of a given powder material can be influenced by a variety of physical and chemical properties including morphology, size, surface state as well as composition of the powder material [2]. Among these influential factors, the laser absorptivity of the powder is one of the key factors because it directly determines how much power the powder can absorb at a certain laser wavelength (1.06 mm for currently most common laser wavelength used in SLM) to form a melt. The laser reflectivity and K-M absorption factor were used to assess the laser absorptivity of the nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg (NTD-Al) powder and nondecorated AlSi10Mg powder. As shown in Fig. 13, the laser
reflectivity of the NTD-Al powder at 1.06 mm laser wavelength was measured to be ~29%, lower than that of non-decorated powder which was ~37%. Concomitantly, the K-M absorption factor of the NTD-Al powder was also higher than the non-decorated powder. This implied that the decorated powder showed an improved laser absorptivity. According to previous studies [38,39], this is due to the high laser absorptivity of non-oxide ceramics. This improved laser absorptivity of the AlSi10Mg powder after decoration with nanoTiB2 is expected to benefit the SLM processability of the NTD-Al powder.

sections.heading: 4.2. Microstructure of SLMed nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg
sections.text:
SLM features a high heating and cooling rate ~103e105 C/s, simultaneously with a high overheating temperature above the liquidus temperature [40]. The solidification microstructures obtained through SLM are expected to be complex, especially the fine cellular-like microstructure in SLM fabricated Al-Si alloys [7,13,41,42]. Several possible mechanisms have been proposed
including the formation of cellular dendrites, Al-Si eutectic as well as non-equilibrium formation of supersaturated Al matrix with nano-Si at the grain boundaries [7,13,43,44]. Recently, Wu et al. proposed another interesting mechanism where the formation of elongated Al grains occurred first and then eutectic Al-Si formed on the surface of the already-formed Al grains [41]. It also showed that adjacent cells have virtually the same orientation and inside the Al grains no obvious orientation relationship between Si and Al was found. However, in this study, a slight crystal orientation deviation in the neighbouring Al cells (shown in Fig. 5) and a certain orientation relation between nano-Si precipitates and Al were observed (shown in Figs. 8 and 9). This implies that a different mechanism may be active during the SLM process. According to our previous study, the Al grains were supersaturated with ~6.5% Si in the asfabricated SLM Al-Si, which is much higher than the equilibrium value of Si in Al (~1.5%) at room temperature [7]. This was attributed to the high cooling rates during SLM which can freeze-in the Si in Al. In this work, the rod-like Si precipitates (shown in Fig. 8) also confirmed the existence of Si inside the Al cells. This was also due to
the aforementioned “freeze-in” effect. Following this, during the SLM process of NTD-Al powder, the formation of supersaturated non-equilibrium Al cells with a high concentration of Si (~2.5% measured by STEM EDX in this study) would solidify first. With the solidification continues, this non-equilibrium state cannot be further retained as the local Si concentration in the molten Al-Si increases towards its eutectic concentration. As a consequence, eutectic Al-Si formed along the boundaries of the already-solidified Al cells, similar to the formation of ultrafine eutectic microstructure in previously reported SLMed Al-12Si [7]. Therefore, the formation of this fine cell microstructure is a process consisting of the
formation of non-equilibrium supersaturated Al cells and eutectic Al-Si at the cell boundaries, which is highly dependent on the cooling rates (freeze-in effect) and local composition. This provides a possible method to tune the actual size of the cells by varying the cooling rates during SLM.
It should be pointed out that the nano-TiB2 particles were mainly found at the boundaries of the Al grains and cells. The reason for this is twofold. First, no melt of TiB2 was observed as evidenced by its unchanged morphology and size before and after the SLM. This was probably due to its very high melting temperature ~3230 C. Second no reaction with Al, Si and Mg at this
temperature within such a short timeframe was reported, an indication of the good chemical stability of TiB2 in molten Al-Si. This is why the TiB2 particles were pushed towards the cell boundaries during the solidification process where eutectic Al-Si formed (shown Figs. 5 and 6). In addition, the average grain size of Al grains in the SLMed material was ~2 mm, much smaller than the grain size in previously reported SLMed Al-Si alloys (~10 mm) [13]. The TiB2 particles are well-known grain growth inhibitors in Al, they have a well-documented crystallographic orientation
relationship which provides high-coherency, thus acting as nuclei for the solidification of Al [32,45]. This is also evidenced by the HRSTEM results in Fig. 7. Thus, the decrease of grain size can be ascribed to a combined effect of the grain refinement of nano-TiB2 particles due to the coherent interface with Al and the high cooling rates during SLM. Furthermore, SLMedmetal parts generally showa strong-textured microstructure due to the directional heat flux and large thermal gradient existing during the SLM process, e.g. a heavy <111> fibre texture has been observed in SLM processed Ta with a 90 zig-zag scanning pattern [30]. Similar results were also observed in high-silicon steel and AlSi10Mg fabricated by SLM [13,31]. The underlying reason was ascribed to the epitaxial grain growth due to the partial remelting of the previous layer, and to a competitive growth mechanism and specific global heat transfer direction during SLM. Apart from the solidification conditions, it is known that the solidification texture of metal parts also can be influenced by many other factors including phase formation and secondary particles [46]. Based on this, the presence of TiB2 particles, especially at the interface as well as the orientation relation between the TiB2 and Al-Si as shown in Fig. 7, was also expected to influence the crystallographic texture of the SLMed Al-Si alloy. This is why no preferred crystallographic texture formed in the SLMed NTD-Al in this study. On-going investigation is being conducted to further reveal the underlying mechanism of the TiB2 particles on the texture formation of SLMed Al-Si alloys.

sections.heading: 4.3. Mechanical properties of SLMed nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg
sections.text:
According to previous studies, the tensile strength of as-SLMed AlSi10Mg without nano-TiB2 is ~360 MPa [47], which is higher than conventional cast and aged AlSi10Mg [37]. The underlying reason was attributed to the fine grain and cell structure as a result of the rapid cooling during SLM. In this work, the as-SLMed NTD-Al had a tensile strength of 530 MPa. The increment in strength is ~170 MPa compared to the as-SLMed AlSi10Mg without nano-TiB2. Since the morphology and size of the grain and cell is similar to that in the asSLMed AlSi10Mg without nano-TiB2 [13,41], this increment in tensile strength here would probably arise from other strengthening mechanisms. It is well known that in metal matrix nanocomposites, there are four possible strengthening mechanisms including increased dislocation density strengthening due to the mismatch of thermal expansion coefficient, Orowan strengthening
via dispersed nano-particles in the matrix, grain boundary strengthening through the Hall-Petch relation and load-bearing strengthening through strong interfacial bonding between the nano-particles and the matrix [48,49].
From the TEM results shown in Figs. 5 and 8, no apparent dislocations were observed in the SLMed NTD-Al material neither in the Al-Si matrix nor around the nano-TiB2 or nano-Si particles. This may be because the nanoparticles were too small to generate enough strain to induce a high density of dislocation around the nano-particles or the dislocations may be annealed out by the dissipated heat from subsequent SLMed powder layers. Therefore, the increased dislocation density strengthening mechanism can be neglected in this study and the increment in strength can be described as below:
Ds ¼ DsOrowan þ DsHall Petch þ Dsload (1) In the SLMed NTD-Al material, both the nano-TiB2 and nano-Si precipitates distributed relatively homogenously at the micrometer-scale. However, most of the nano-TiB2 was distributed along the grain or cell boundaries. Therefore, the contribution by the Orowan strengthening (DsOrowan) mechanism induced by nanoTiB2 (DsOrowan;TiB2 ) can be neglected while the contribution from nano-Si (DsOrowan;Si) inside the cells can be estimated by the following equation [48]:
DsOrowanzDsOrowan;Si ¼ 4Gmb dp;Si 6Vp;Si p 1=3 (2)
where Gm and b are the shear modulus of the matrix (~26.5 GPa) and the Burgers vector (~0.286 nm), respectively. dp;Si and Vp;Si are the volume fraction (~2.5 vol%) and the size of the nano-Si (~70 nm), respectively. 4 is a constant around the order of 2. As such, the calculated DsOrowan is 79 MPa. It is noteworthy that for simplification the above calculation does not take the shape and orientation of precipitates into consideration, which is reported to also have an influence on the dispersion strengthening in alloys according to Nie et al. [50].
The EBSD images of the SLMed NTD-Al samples also showed a very fine grain microstructure with the grain size ~2 mm (Fig. 4). According to the Hall-Petch relationship, the contribution by the grain boundary strengthening mechanism (DsHall Petch) can be calculated as below:
DsHall Petch ¼ kd 1=2 (3)
where k is a constant and d is the grain size. According to previous study [51], k is set to 50 MPa ffiffiffiffiffiffiffi mm p . Thus, the calculated strength increment by the grain boundary strengthening mechanism (DsHall Petch) is ~20 MPa. As such, the contribution to the increment in strength induced by the load-bearing mechanism (Dsload) was ~71 MPa. Therefore, according the load-bearing mechanism shown as below (where Vp is volume fraction of the nano-particles and in this study Vp was taken ~7 vol%) [52]:
Dsload ¼ 1:5Vpsi (4) The bonding strength between the nano-particles and the Al-Si matrix si can be estimated ~676 MPa, implying a relatively strong interface bonding. This is consistent with the TEM results where a highly coherent interfacewas found between the nano-TiB2 and the Al matrix. Meanwhile, a perfect coherent interface between nanoSi and Al matrix was also observed.
It is known that for simple metals, the ductility can be enhanced mainly through three possible mechanisms: a bimodal grain structure, nano-particle additions and non-equilibrium grain boundaries [48]. In this study, the NTD-Al is a complex nanocomposite which probably cannot be directly explained using these three mechanisms with regards to the observed enhancement of ductility. For complex alloys, there are very few established theories for ductility enhancement [48]. However, according to recent studies on nanocomposites, grain boundary modification (size and population of the nano-particles) can enhance the ductility in nanocomposites [48]. The underlying mechanismwas attributed to a suppression of grain boundary cracking caused by particle fracture and interfacial decohesion. In this study, the well-dispersed TiB2 nano-particles would probably modify the cells boundaries, which can promote the formation of more dislocations during deformation. Similar results have also been reported for nano-TiC reinforced AlSi10Mg fabricated by SLM, the TiC reinforcement at the grain boundaries can constrain crack propagation during plastic deformation [17]. Another mechanism for enhancing ductility could be promoted dislocation plasticity (nucleate and pin down/ store dislocations) due to the existence of nano-particles inside the matrix. This mechanism has been used to explain the ductility enhancement in age-hardenable alloys such as ultrafine grained (UFG) Al alloys [53,54]. In this work, the nano-Si precipitates inside the cells could promote the formation of dislocations during deformation. All of these together would probably be the reason for the observed enhanced ductility. It is noteworthy that apart from the aforementioned two possible mechanisms bi- or multi-modal grain structure, similar to cell structure in this study, is also an efficient method for achieving a simultaneous enhancement of tensile strength and ductility [55]. However, to unravel the underlying mechanism for the observed enhanced ductility in this study, more detailed investigation will be carried out in the near future.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, a 7 vol% in-situ nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg (NTD-Al) composite powder was designed and gas-atomised for selective laser melting (SLM). Fully dense and crack-free NTD-Al nanocomposites were fabricated using optimised SLM parameters. The processing-microstructure-mechanical properties correlation was established, allowing to draw the following conclusions:
(1) Addition of nano-TiB2 can increase the laser absorptivity of the AlSi10Mg powder by ~50% compared to non-decorated powder, which further benefits the SLM processability of the NTD-Al powder. (2) In contrast to previously reported SLMed Al-Si alloys or exsitu formed Al-Si composites, the SLMed NTD-Al material had a textureless microstructure, consisting of fine grains and cell structure, with nano-TiB2 uniformly distributed along the grain and cell boundaries and rod-like nano-Si precipitates inside the cells. Both nano-TiB2 and nano-Si exhibited a highly coherent interface with the Al matrix, indicative of a strong interfacial bonding. The formation of this novel microstructure was related to the nano-TiB2 and the rapid solidification during SLM, which enable the formation of non-equilibrium supersaturated Al cells and eutectic Al-Si at the cell boundaries. (3) The SLMed NTD-Al composites had a high tensile strength of 530 ± 16 MPa, excellent ductility ~15.5 ± 1.2% and microhardness 191 ± 4 HV0.3, which were higher than most conventionally fabricated wrought and tempered Al alloys, and previously reported SLMed Al-Si alloys as well as coarseand nano-grain 7075 Al. The increased strength was mainly attributed to Hall-Petch, loading-bearing and Orowan strengthening mechanisms, while the enhancement in ductility was caused by grain boundarymodification through the presence of nano-TiB2 particles and promoted dislocation plasticity in the bulk of the grains by nano-Si precipitates.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was supported by the Flemish Agency for Innovation by Science and Technology (IWT) Strategic Basic Research (SBO) project “MultiMet”. The TEM facility in Lille, France, is supported by the Conseil Regional du Nord-Pas de Calais and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF). The authors are grateful for the project supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 51201099). The authors would like to thank Prof. Christopher Hutchinson from Monash University for valuable discussion on microstructure and mechanical properties. The authors would also like to thank Dr. Wouter Baekelant from Department of Chemistry, KU Leuven for powder laser absorptivity measurement.

As such, the drawbacks of this process are apparent: (1) in most cases, the added fine secondary particles (diameter 5 mm) would deteriorate the flowability of the matrix powder [2]; (2) due to different laser absorptivity of the ceramic particles, an apparent difference in thermal history between the ceramic particles and the metals would be inevitable, which can also affect or complicate the melt pool behavior [24]; and (3) although some in-situ reaction can be introduced to improve the interfacial bonding between the reinforcement particles and the matrix [16], this improvement is limited because the wettability of the metal matrix and secondary metal or ceramic particles is difficult to control.

As a consequence, eutectic Al-Si formed along the boundaries of the already-solidified Al cells, similar to the formation of ultrafine eutectic microstructure in previously reported SLMed Al-12Si [7].
In addition, the average grain size of Al grains in the SLMed material was ~2 mm, much smaller than the grain size in previously reported SLMed Al-Si alloys (~10 mm) [13].

It is known that for simple metals, the ductility can be enhanced mainly through three possible mechanisms: a bimodal grain structure, nano-particle additions and non-equilibrium grain boundaries [48].
For complex alloys, there are very few established theories for ductility enhancement [48].
However, according to recent studies on nanocomposites, grain boundary modification (size and population of the nano-particles) can enhance the ductility in nanocomposites [48].

metadata.abstractText: An in-situ nano-TiB2 decorated AlSi10Mg composite (NTD-Al) powder was fabricated by gas-atomisation for selective laser melting (SLM). Fully dense and crack-free NTD-Al samples were produced using SLM. In contrast to the NTD-Al powder without cell-like microstructure, the SLMed NTD-Al had a textureless microstructure, consisting of fine grains and cells, with well dispersed nano-TiB2 particles inside the grains and rod-like nano-Si precipitates inside the cells. Both nano-TiB2 particles and nano-Si precipitates exhibited a highly coherent interface with the Al matrix, indicative of a strong interfacial bonding. The formation of this microstructure was attributed to the sequential solidification of non-equilibrium and eutectic Al-Si upon rapid cooling during SLM. As a result, the SLMed NTD-Al showed a very high ultimate tensile strength ~530 MPa, excellent ductility ~15.5% and high microhardness ~191 HV0.3, which were higher than most conventionally fabricated wrought and tempered Al alloys, previously SLMed Al-Si alloys and nano-grained 7075 Al. The underlying mechanisms for this strength and ductility enhancement were discussed and a correlation between this novel microstructure and the superior mechanical properties was established. This study provides new and deep insights into the fabrication of metal matrix nanocomposites by SLM from in-situ pre-decorated composite powder. © 2017 Acta Materialia Inc. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
